node.text: A conversation with landscape architect Janice Parker

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Jupiter, Florida. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Wabi-sabi, the Japanese design principle that emphasizes the perfectly imperfect, became a design imperative for the interiors of this Jupiter Island retreat by designer Betsy Brown (@betsybrowninc). It was up to Brown to pair the couple's worldly collections with vintage items and natural materials seen in the architectural work done by Thomas Melhorn (@thomas.melhorn). 

"It was all about building imperfection," Brown says. "As a family grows, this house will only continue to add memories. We sought a lot of comfortable furniture, durable fabrics, and worn work tables without finishes because the wear would be an added benefit."

The staircase features two of the main materials used throughout the home: wax plaster and lime cypress, the latter being a native wood to South Florida. 

Tap the link to see inside this Jupiter Island retreat. 
—
Photography by Nicole Franzen (@nicole_franzen).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Mountain Brook, Alabama. May be an image of furniture and living room.

node.text:
Interior designer Melanie Pounds (@melaniepoundsinteriordesign) played the role of matchmaker in this Alabama cottage, pairing together the owners' individual antique collections and artworks. 

“Both Gene and my mom have fabulous taste, so it was fun. My job was to take what they had, make it work together, then fill in the holes,” she explains. Generous banks of steel-cased windows frame a salon punctuated with a mix of hand-hewn antiques. The cozy sofas are by @verellenfurniture and @dmitriyco.

See the inside of this enchanting Birmingham home at the link in bio.
—
Architecture by Paul Bates (@paulbatesarchitects)
Landscape design by Norman Johnson (@norman_johnson_gardens)
Contractors, TCC General Contractors (@tcc_contractors)
Photography by Brian Woodcock (@bwfoto)
Produced by Rachael Burrow (@rachaelburrow)
Written by Stephanie Hunt (@stephhuntwrites)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Washington, Connecticut. May be an image of table and living room.

node.text:
For interiors of this 270-year-old Connecticut house, designer Philip Gorrivan (@philipgorrivan) did extensive research on Colonial New England architecture as part of his efforts to respect the spirit of the original house.

“There’s always a temptation when you have a blank slate to do interesting decorative things,” says the designer. “The truth is, a house like that probably didn’t have paneled walls everywhere. I really wanted to keep it closer to the way I thought it would have been.”

He added millwork throughout: trim moldings around windows and doors, wainscoting or even fully paneled walls in some rooms, simple chair rails in others. Horizontal paneling (painted Smoke Embers by @benjaminmoore) wraps around the breakfast room. The window shade fabric by de Le Cuona (@delecuona).

Tap the link in bio to see more of this 1750s Connecticut home.
—

Photography by Joshua McHugh (@joshuamchughphotography)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Upper West Side. May be an image of kitchen island, range hood and kitchen.

node.text:
What's cooking? ✨ In this Anthony Baratta-designed kitchen, the New York apartment's original mosaic tile floors endure, and inspired the fleur-de-lis wallpaper in the dining area. The banquette is upholstered in “1940s glam” diamond-patterned leathers (@dualoyleather). The table is a Biedermeier reproduction commissioned by Anthony Baratta (@tonybaratta), while the profile of the window pelmet (@norbarfabrics) is pure theater. 

Take a full tour of this Manhattan apartment at the link in bio!
–
Photography by Mark Roskams (@mark_roskams)
Written by Celia Barbour

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Jupiter, Florida. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
After growing up in Palm Beach County and returning to the charming town of Jupiter, Florida, architect and contractor Christian Thomas of Thomas Melhorn (@thomas.melhorn) has become more than just a designer of homes—he helps his clients achieve their wildest dreams of coastal living. 

The architect teamed up with Birmingham-based designer Betsy Brown (@betsybrowninc) to turn one family's vision of a timeless yet ultra-livable seaside home in Jupiter into a reality.

"The evolution of this project began with one of the clients' requirements being that, as a tight-knit family, they really wanted this home to be a legacy that could live on for a long time, so we started off with this concept of memory and recording time throughout the house," says Thomas. "Every material was selected in that vein so that it would grow more beautiful with age."

Even though the home is a new build, Thomas’s use of native woods and techniques gives the materials an effortless patina and makes it feel deeply rooted in the landscape. This hideaway kitchen is the perfect place to house fresh-from-the-garden fruits and prep festive libations come happy hour. The pendants are by Kevin Reilly Collection (@kevinreillycollection). 

Want to learn how wabi-sabi impacted the way the rest of the home was decorated? Tap the link in bio. 
—
Photography by Nicole Franzen (@nicole_franzen).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Mountain Brook, Alabama. May be an image of tree, door, brick wall and outdoors.

node.text:
In lieu of a formal entry, visitors to this dreamy Alabama cottage enter through the laidback loggia. “[My clients] like the casual simplicity of friends coming in the back door,” explains architect Paul Bates (@paulbatesarchitects).

Since the loggia looks onto a meadow, landscape architect Norman Johnson (@norman_johnson_gardens) amplified the sense of rural ease with a low stone wall framing the views, through which a pea gravel driveway meanders to a motor court, all flanked by fields of wildflowers and clover. 

Louvred doors to the expansive loggia are painted Pigeon by Farrow & Ball (@farrowandball).

See the inside of this enchanting Birmingham home at the link in bio.
—
Interior design by Melanie Pounds (@melaniepoundsinteriordesign)
Contractors, TCC General Contractors (@tcc_contractors)
Photography by Brian Woodcock (@bwfoto)
Produced by Rachael Burrow (@rachaelburrow)
Written by Stephanie Hunt (@stephhuntwrites)

node.text:
Postcards from Lecce, Italy. ✨

📸: @bmseventh
📍: Lecce, Italy
#regram

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Maine. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Welcome into a harbor-front house filled with surprises. You enter what appears to be a quintessential Maine cottage, then stumble into an impressive living room with double height and furniture from a completely different place and time period. 

"It reflects my clients so well," says architect Gil Schafer (@gpschafer). "Like that experience, they too are so rare and unexpected."

In the entryway, an early-20th-century brass lantern (@humphreycarrasco) hangs beneath the daylight, a glazed panel allowing light from a pair of double-hung windows above.

See more of this cozy Maine cottage at the link in bio.
—
Landscape design by Stephen Mohr

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Atlanta, Georgia. May be an image of stripes, furniture and living room.

node.text:
Our current design obsession: anything and everything chartreuse. In their 1960s apartment in Atlanta, designer John Oetgen (@johnoetgen) and John Lineweaver deployed the vivacious color to act as the background to their world-class art collection. Chartreuse stripes throughout the breakfast room connect it to the neighboring kitchen. The banquette is covered in a Jerry Pair (@jerrypair) leather.
—
Photography by Thomas Loof (@thomasloof), from the VER archive.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Chateau du Grand-Lucé. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
France's Loire Valley is calling our name. ✨ At his palatial Château du Grand-Lucé, Los Angeles-based designer Timothy Corrigan (@timothycorrigan) loosens up the garden with a relaxed, refined sensibility. 
—
Photography by Eric Piasecki (@ericpiasecki), from the VER archive.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Veranda Magazine in Washington, Connecticut. May be an image of bedroom.

node.text:
New York-based decorator Philip Gorrivan (@philipgorrivan) worked to restore the revolutionary spirit of this 270-year-old Connecticut house while honoring the owners' heritage. Swedish influences pop out throughout the Colonial home including this quaint guest bedroom. A 19th-century Gustavian bed pairs with a painted antique chest and 20th-century table lamp (both Swedish). The pillow fabric is Philip Gorrivan for Baker (@bakerfurniture).

Tap the link in bio to see more of this 1750s Connecticut home.
—

Photography by Joshua McHugh (@joshuamchughphotography)
Written by Stephen Wallis (@stephen_wallis)
